content.description: <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O H aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus C H 3 C H 2 C O O with a negative 1 charge aqueous. K sub a equals 1.4 times 10 to the negative 5 power at 25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>COO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>) </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext>at</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O with a negative 1 charge aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with C H 3 C H 2 C O O H aqueous plus O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous. K sub b equals 7.4 times 10 to the negative 10 power at 25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>COO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>7.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext>at</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The acid equilibrium for <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the base equilibrium for <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>COO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are represented above. One liter of a buffer solution with <math alttext="p H equals 4.85" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>4.85</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is made by mixing <math alttext="0.100 molar C H 3 C H 2 C O O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.100 molar N a C H 3 C H 2 C O O " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NaCH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If <math alttext="10.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.500 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is added to the buffer, which of the following is most likely the resulting <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be much less than 4.85, because the buffer will respond to the addition of <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by producing more <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be much greater than 4.85, because there is a large increase in the concentration of the weak base, <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>COO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be slightly less than 4.85, because the addition of <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> reduces the autoionization of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be slightly greater than 4.85, because some <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will react with the added base, resulting in a slight decrease in <math alttext="the molar concentration of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be slightly greater than 4.85, because some <math alttext="C H 3 C H 2 C O O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will react with the added base, resulting in a slight decrease in <math alttext="the molar concentration of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
